answers.answer: Hi!Since there is trembling and pain, pinched nerves could be a cause.  Before resuming any sport, this aspect should be investigated through nerve conduction studies and MRI of the cervical and thoracic spine. Tendon and muscle injury is another possibility. It can also be peripheral neuropathy due to diabetes or thyroid disorder. It is necessary she consult a sports injury specialist before resuming any sport. Take care!The medical advice given should not be considered a substitute for medical care provided by a doctor who can examine you. The advice may not be completely correct for you as the doctor cannot examine you and does not know your complete medical history. Hence this reply to your post should only be considered as a guiding line and you must consult your doctor at the earliest for your medical problem.

question: Thank you in advance for reading my question.My daughter is 15 and in very good overall health.  She is quite athletic, and plays high school basketball and softball, as well as competitive travel fastpitch softball for 6 months per year from May to November.  She sees a personal trainer 2X per week and works out regularly on her own.She is a pitcher for her fastpitch softball team, and sees her pitching instructor regularly.  She has been pitching for about 5-6 years now.  A few weekends ago, at a tournament, she began experiencing symptoms she has never felt before.The fingertips on her pitching (right) hand began hurting.  She always has a few rough spots on her fingers from the laces on the softball, but she described it as a deeper pain, as if her fingertips were bruised.  There are no visual changes noted with her fingers.  I assumed it was due to pitching, but later that day, she said that her left fingertips were feeling the same way.  She says they are tender all the time now, as if she had cut all over her fingernails too short.  When she presses on them, they feel bruised.  Within the last 1-2 weeks, she has noticed that her fingers are trembling spontaneously for a few seconds, then they will quit.  Her fingers are quite weak now, and she is having trouble gripping the bat, the ball, and even catching with her glove.  She rarely complains about injuries, but this is really affecting her.  When she is pitching, I notice her shaking her right hand.  We have tried ibuprofen, ice, pain relief, etc, but we can't seem to remedy it.Any ideas?Thank you again!
title: Very Active Teen - Trembling, Sore Fingers
